body: How about "Powered by IPython v..."?  It's a bit longer, but it's more in line with common web practice.

> How about "Powered by IPython v..."? It's a bit longer, but it's more in line with common web practice.

Well technically it si not "powered by .." as it is IPython, but at suppose any project based on IPython could prepend "powered by". But I'm no native english, I might be wrong on my understanding on "Powered by".
I agree with @Carreau - 'powered by' is suitable for frameworks and things, it sounds silly for an application.

On Sat, Sep 27, 2014 at 3:36 PM, Thomas Kluyver notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I agree with @Carreau https://github.com/Carreau - 'powered by' is
> suitable for frameworks and things, it sounds silly for an application.

I think Jason's suggestion is valid, if you change it to "Powered by
Jupyter", which is indeed a framework.

> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/6554#issuecomment-57063260.

Once we do the separation and renaming, the notebook will be the Jupyter notebook, so it would still be "Jupyter v4.0", with no need for "powered by".

"Powered by" would be for something like tornado, apache or Python - underlying technologies used to run the application.
I don't think it makes sense for this to be always visible. Maybe put it in an About link from a menu?

I'm working on about dialog in a separate branch, 
I think an about page should have much more info. 

I still believe a discrete footer would be nice.
And it's not always there, it is a footer, so you have to scroll down :-)

Also there is no about menu on non-notebook page.

Le 27 sept. 2014 Ã  23:05, Min RK notifications@github.com a Ã©crit :

> I don't think it makes sense for this to be always visible. Maybe put it in an About link from a menu?
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Footer might be okay on non-notebook pages. I wouldn't put it on the notebook page, though. That's not information you generally need or want, so it doesn't make much sense to always display it on every page.

Took a shot at draft of About screen. 
![capture d ecran 2014-09-28 a 16 53 11](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/335567/4434647/71bf81f6-471f-11e4-868b-8091664755b2.png)

We can discuss at the information you want to add to about screen.

+1 on an "About" dialog... that _could_ make tracking down things easier.
Don't like the "this might not be the right kernel information". It _could_
be a really useful info page that allows the kernel to supply additional
details about the kernel version, installed libraries, extensions, and
other specific details.

On Sun, Sep 28, 2014 at 10:56 AM, Matthias Bussonnier <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Took a shot at draft of About screen.
> [image: capture d ecran 2014-09-28 a 16 53 11]
> https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/335567/4434647/71bf81f6-471f-11e4-868b-8091664755b2.png
> 
> We can discuss at the information you want to add to about screen.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/6554#issuecomment-57087933.

But the "about" page give info about the **server** in most cases (right now) it will be the same version as what the kernel is (for Python). I don't thing design of a message to ask the kernel its version is in scope now. (especially I don't want to add into the about page a potentially long and blocking call to the kernel). 

That being said, what about a file in kernel spec directory that add extra text that depends on the kernel ? This could instruct user how to get information about the kernel. Or just freeze kernel info at kernelspec installation time.

(Proposition that will most likely not be part of this PR)

It could include information from the kernel_info_reply - there's already a banner field in there that may have relevant text, and there are fields for kernel version and language version. But I agree that that can go in in a later PR.

As I mentioned here: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/3025#issuecomment-57306929, I would love to see the info in the footer but I would be happy with the about page too... probably the footer could be an extension... @Carreau I think I would steal some of your code here :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:

Thinking a bit more about it; I'm wondering if we should show information on non-logged-in page as it is potentially a future security by showing to a potential attacker that IPython version is not up-to date. 

Will rebase and clean.

![capture d ecran 2014-10-03 a 09 15 57](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/335567/4502745/281c33bc-4acd-11e4-8cda-a00f2075a67c.png)

Rebased and cleaned. + Kernel Info (`kinfo.banner` actually)

That looks nice and useful! I wonder if you could also use the `help_links` in the kernelspec to provide a easy way to click to find more info about the kernel... it may not be obvious that a kernel has added menu options under Help, and this dialog could help direct users to given URLs.
Help links in the kernel spec are supposed to replace the link in the .... help menu. But separate PR.

@Carreau Yes, I know, but it might not be obvious to a user that the Help menu can tell you more about the kernel. Perhaps there could be a special "About" key in help_links that could appear in this dialog, too.

I think I don't completely understand. You want an about dialog in the about dialog ? 

Also I think that the server is Python is an implementation details. People using IHaskell, or IJulia, just don't get why the help links are not about their kernel. And right now the about menu is the only place that leak information about the server, and it is mostly not for lambda user, it will be used IMHO for debug purposes.

@Carreau I meant to suggest that you could put a _link_ in the about dialog to the kernel help URL that is from the help_links kernelspec field. Rather than putting all of these links, perhaps only if there is a help_links["About"] link. This might be an easy way to find out if your kernel is up to date, for example (eg, notebook menu -> About -> dialog -> click "About kernel..." which the kernel maintainer would have a webpage with news, updates, getting started links etc)

4 level is too deep IMHO, but as the full\* help menu will be in control of the kernels maintainers, I don't see any reason to add a specific hook for that. 

More specifically if you can do that : 
![capture d ecran 2014-10-03 a 16 21 46](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/335567/4507009/aa2ef7dc-4b08-11e4-967b-5d09f1fd6e4b.png)

You can add an "About Kernel", or whatever. 

[*] except the about dialog
Rebased.
I am very +1 on the "About" idea - awesome!
Seems to need another rebase...
+1 for footer with just `IPython x.x.x` for the start to cover the #3025. Everything else is out of scope. If more info is needed, the bottom corner can be made clickable/expandable.
rebasd.
I see there's still a footer. I don't think the IPython version should always be displayed on every page.

I agree with @minrk on this.

On Tue, Oct 14, 2014 at 3:08 PM, Min RK notifications@github.com wrote:

> I see there's still a footer. I don't think the IPython version should
> always be displayed on every page.
